texts.shortText: Unusual species in which the head is retracted between the anterior body segments and is concealed by a prominent circular ‘cage’ of long, forward-projecting, stiff, annulated setae. The body is stiff and covered with rings of tiny wart-like papillae. The posterior end is strongly tapered and usually bent, or reflexed forward.

Global: There are over 40 species globally in this genus including several from South Africa and these are difficult to distinguish, so we can only identify images to genus level.

Local/Regional: Unknown, as species not identified.

Thought to live in rock crevices and holes and to hold the body in a U-shape, so as to eject faeces from the opening of the hole. Feed using a pair of frilly palps in the head to sweep detritus from the setal cage.
Detritus feeders, picking up organic material with frilly palps on the head.
Little is known about reproduction in this group, but sexes are separate and it is assumed that eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.

The stiff cages of elongate setae around the head are characteristic. The Flabby bristleworm Flabelligera affinis belongs to the same family and has a similar, but much smaller, anteriorsetal cage, but that species in much softer and more mobile and is also covered in a sheath of green mucus.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 72).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 743).

Seitz, RD & Schaffer, LC (1995). Population ecology and secondary production of the polychaete Loimia medusa (Terebellidae). Marine Biology, 121, 701-711.
